review.title: Leveraging Semantic Web Search and Browse Sessions for Multi-Turn Spoken Dialog Systems
review.abstract: Training statistical dialog models in spoken dialog systems (SDS) requires large amounts of annotated data. The lack of scalable methods for data mining and annotation poses a significant hurdle for state-of-the-art statistical dialog managers. This paper presents an approach that directly leverage billions of web search and browse sessions to overcome this hurdle. The key insight is that task completion through web search and browse sessions is (a) predictable and (b) generalizes to spoken dialog task completion. The new method automatically mines behavioral search and browse patterns from web logs and translates them into spoken dialog models. We experiment with naturally occurring spoken dialogs and large scale web logs. Our session-based models outperform the state-of-the-art method for entity extraction task in SDS. We also achieve better performance for both entity and relation extraction on web search queries when compared with nontrivial baselines.

sections.heading: 3.1. Pilot Study: Entity-based Search Session Modeling
sections.text: We first conduct experiments to confirm our session assumption, i.e. the current search behavior depends on the search history. Formally, a search session S is represented by a sequence of units e0, e1, · · ·, el, as described in Section 2.2. We calculate the probability of the sessions on the basis of Markov models with different histories, the higher order model taking into account a longer history. The probability of the session S is expressed as the product of the units of which S is composed, where the probability of each unit depends on the previous n − 1 units (i.e. order-n): P (S) = 1 P (ei | i − 1 i − n + 1), where e j i denotes the sequence ei,..., ej. sections.heading: 3.2. Results: Entity and Relation Extraction
sections.text: Due to the large size of the test data, we automatically acquire designations by comparing queries and units with names longer than two words in the Gazetteer. The resulting designations are taken as the gold standard for evaluation. As some of our classifier's predictions are outside the Gazetteer, underestimating accuracy, we only report callbacks to measure how many units or relationships are retrieved from the models. In the test phase, we assume that our models only have access to the part of the Gazetteer that has been observed in training. Compare. We compare 1) two baselines and 2) a linear CRF that predicts entity spans and their types simultaneously [13]. Baseline 1 (Gazetteer Only) is constructed by comparing the units in the Gazetteer with the queries, selecting the longest matching when a token is mapped to multiple units. For Baseline 2 (no session), we follow [25] to establish a significantly better relationship between the units in the query and the results.
